articles.headline: Justices Say GPS Tracker Violated Privacy Rights
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court unanimously ruled that putting a tracking device on a suspect’s car violated his rights, although they differed on why.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court unanimously ruled that putting a tracking device on a suspect’s car violated his rights, although they differed on why.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday  ruled unanimously that the police violated the Constitution when they placed a Global Positioning System tracking device on a suspect’s car and monitored its movements for 28 days.

articles.headline: Ex-C.I.A. Officer Charged in Information Leak
articles.snippet: John Kiriakou is charged with disclosing to journalists the identity of a C.I.A. analyst who worked on a 2002 operation that seized and interrogated Abu Zubaydah, a top Qaeda operative.
articles.abstract: John Kiriakou is charged with disclosing to journalists the identity of a C.I.A. analyst who worked on a 2002 operation that seized and interrogated Abu Zubaydah, a top Qaeda operative.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department on Monday charged a former Central Intelligence Agency officer with disclosing classified information to journalists about the capture and brutal interrogation of a suspected member of Al Qaeda, Abu Zubaydah — adding another chapter to the Obama administration’s crackdown on leaks.

articles.headline: Permanent Rescue Fund Seems Nearer in Europe
articles.snippet: As euro zone finance ministers gathered in Brussels to discuss the Greek debt crisis, Christine Lagarde said a “larger firewall” was needed to safeguard global financial stability.
articles.abstract: As euro zone finance ministers gathered in Brussels to discuss the Greek debt crisis, Christine Lagarde said a “larger firewall” was needed to safeguard global financial stability.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European finance ministers increased pressure on Greek bondholders to take voluntary losses to ease the region’s debt crisis late Monday and took new steps to complete action on a new bailout fund as the International Monetary Fund had urged.
articles.byline: By James Kanter and David Jolly

articles.headline: Not Quite Smart Enough
articles.snippet: As the “smart” gadget revolution spreads from phones to televisions and home appliances, some manufacturers are hoping to make a bundle.
articles.abstract: As the “smart” gadget revolution spreads from phones to televisions and home appliances, some manufacturers are hoping to make a bundle.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the “smart” revolution spreads from phones to other electronics, some manufacturers are hoping to make a bundle by selling refrigerators that spew out recipes based on what’s inside, robotic vacuum cleaners with remote-controlled cameras, and washers and dryers you can monitor from your phone.

articles.headline: Europe Weighs Tough Law on Online Privacy
articles.snippet: A proposed law in Europe would compel Web sites to obtain consent when collecting personal data and to delete that data forever at the consumer’s request.
articles.abstract: A proposed law in Europe would compel Web sites to obtain consent when collecting personal data and to delete that data forever at the consumer’s request.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Europe is considering a sweeping new law that would force Internet companies like Amazon.com and Facebook to obtain explicit consent from consumers about the use of their personal data, delete that data forever at the consumer’s request and face fines for failing to comply.

articles.headline: ‘Super PAC’ for Gingrich to Get $5 Million Infusion
articles.snippet: Dr. Miriam Adelson, the wife of Sheldon Adelson, is a longtime Gingrich friend and patron who contributed $5 million to the super PAC, Winning Our Future, this month.
articles.abstract: Dr. Miriam Adelson, the wife of Sheldon Adelson, is a longtime Gingrich friend and patron who contributed $5 million to the super PAC, Winning Our Future, this month.
articles.lead_paragraph: A wealthy backer of Newt Gingrich will inject $5 million into a “super PAC” supporting his presidential bid, two people with knowledge of the contribution said on Monday, providing a major boost to Mr. Gingrich as he seeks to fend off aggressive attacks from Mitt Romney, his main Republican rival.

articles.headline: Political Push Moves a Deal on Mortgages Inches Closer
articles.snippet: About one million homeowners facing foreclosure could have their mortgage burden cut by about $20,000 each as part of a long-awaited deal.
articles.abstract: About one million homeowners facing foreclosure could have their mortgage burden cut by about $20,000 each as part of a long-awaited deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: About one million homeowners facing foreclosure could have their mortgage burden cut by about $20,000 each as part of a long-awaited deal taking shape among state attorneys general, federal officials and the nation’s largest mortgage servicers.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Shaila Dewan

articles.headline: Romney Unleashes Attack With Gingrich Sole Target
articles.snippet: In Florida on Monday, Mitt Romney was on the offensive for the first time in a series of G.O.P. debates, tearing into Newt Gingrich’s time as House speaker and the years when he advised companies like Freddie Mac.
articles.abstract: In Florida on Monday, Mitt Romney was on the offensive for the first time in a series of G.O.P. debates, tearing into Newt Gingrich’s time as House speaker and the years when he advised companies like Freddie Mac.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Mitt Romney leveled a searing attack against Newt Gingrich’s character and raised pointed questions about his ability to lead during a debate here Monday evening, taking urgent steps to slow Mr. Gingrich’s rising momentum in the fight for the Republican presidential nomination.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: With DNA Testing, Suddenly They Are Family
articles.snippet: When access to adoption records is blocked, people have another avenue for finding clues to their ancestry and connections to blood relatives.
articles.abstract: When access to adoption records is blocked, people have another avenue for finding clues to their ancestry and connections to blood relatives.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — Growing up, Khrys Vaughan always believed that she had inherited her looks and mannerisms from her father, and that her appreciation for tradition and old-fashioned gentility stemmed from her parents’ Southern roots. But those facets of her self-image crumbled when she was told, at age 42, that she had been adopted.
